importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The article was updated on October 21, 2025, and is a current report on policy changes affecting VA mental health care, indicating ongoing concerns in the system.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The policy push to limit therapy sessions intensified starting in 2021, particularly after Doug Collins became VA Secretary in January 2021, and continues into 2025.

keyTakeAways: VA therapists and patients report that one-on-one therapy sessions are being abruptly limited or terminated, even when patients have chronic mental health conditions like PTSD.

The policy, introduced under earlier administrations and intensified under President Donald Trump’s administration, restricts long-term therapy to a fixed number of sessions (4–24) without clinical discretion.
Providers report facing disciplinary consequences for challenging session limits, including loss of practice privileges or being required to justify extensions in writing.
Veterans with severe or chronic conditions, such as PTSD, feel abandoned and re-traumatized when therapy ends prematurely.
The VA denies that limits exist, claiming care is personalized and based on shared decisions, but providers and veterans say the system undermines trust and clinical appropriateness.
Some mental health providers have resigned due to frustration with the policy, exacerbating a VA-wide staff shortage.
The American Psychological Association has acknowledged reports and is investigating, emphasizing the need for individualized, recovery-oriented care.
Veterans express discomfort with alternatives like group therapy or re-applying, especially when they have built strong therapeutic relationships.

namedEntities.name: Michael
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A combat veteran with PTSD who used a pseudonym to speak about his mental health struggles and therapy limitations.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Michael exemplifies the personal impact of the policy: his therapy was abruptly terminated, leading him to feel abandoned and re-traumatized, illustrating the human cost of session limits.

namedEntities.name: VA (Veterans Affairs)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The U.S. government agency responsible for providing healthcare and mental health services to veterans.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The VA is central to the issue — its policy changes regarding therapy session limits are at the heart of the article’s controversy over access, quality, and appropriateness of care.

namedEntities.name: Doug Collins
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The VA Secretary appointed by President Donald Trump in January 2021, whose administration oversaw the policy push to limit therapy sessions.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Collins is directly linked to the intensified policy changes targeting therapy limits, making him a key political figure in the article’s narrative.

namedEntities.name: Peter Kasperowicz
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: VA spokesperson who denied that session limits exist and emphasized shared decision-making in care planning.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Kasperowicz represents the official VA position, which contradicts reports from providers and patients, highlighting the conflict between institutional messaging and on-the-ground realities.

namedEntities.name: Caitlin Thompson
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former VA psychologist now working in the private sector, who noted that limited sessions are common in private healthcare but must be clinically appropriate.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Thompson provides a counterpoint to the VA policy, suggesting that limits are not inherently inappropriate in all settings, but must be contextually justified.

namedEntities.name: Stephen Long
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former VA psychologist at Northport VA Medical Center who retired in 2024 due to session-limiting policies.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Long’s resignation underscores the impact of policy on staff retention and highlights concerns about trust and long-term care needs.

namedEntities.name: Mark Jorges
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former psychotherapist and mental health counselor at a VA hospital in Temple, Texas, who resigned in May 2024 due to therapy limits.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Jorges’ resignation reflects broader dissatisfaction among mental health providers and supports claims that policy implementation lacks clinical sensitivity.

namedEntities.name: Jake Pannell
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Army veteran receiving long-term one-on-one therapy for PTSD and anxiety at a Washington state VA facility.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Pannell illustrates the frustration of veterans facing abrupt termination of care, even in stable, long-term treatment, and questions the logic of limiting therapy for chronic conditions.

namedEntities.name: American Psychological Association (APA)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The largest professional organization for psychologists in the U.S., which is investigating reports of therapy session limits.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The APA’s involvement signals external validation of concerns and emphasizes the need for recovery-oriented, patient-centered care.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Veterans and mental health providers are raising alarm over a policy shift within the U.S. Veterans Affairs (VA) system that restricts long-term one-on-one therapy sessions, particularly for veterans with chronic conditions like PTSD. The policy, intensified since 2021 under VA Secretary Doug Collins, mandates fixed session limits (typically 4–24) and limits provider discretion to extend care, even when patients need ongoing treatment. Providers report facing disciplinary action for challenging the policy, and some have resigned due to frustration. Veterans like Michael and Jake Pannell describe feeling abandoned and re-traumatized when therapy is abruptly ended. Critics argue that the policy undermines clinical judgment, violates shared decision-making, and fails to recognize the chronic nature of mental health conditions. While the VA denies such limits exist and claims care is personalized, providers and veterans say the system prioritizes volume over quality and trust. The American Psychological Association is investigating, underscoring broader concerns about access, equity, and the long-term well-being of veterans in need of sustained mental health care.
title: VA Therapists and Veterans Report Therapy Sessions Being Limited, Sparking Outrage Over Patient Care
